intro: Potamogeton obtusifolius subf. acutus, commonly known as the sharp-leaf pondweed, is a submerged aquatic plant native to freshwater environments in Europe and Asia. It is characterized by its narrow, linear leaves that are typically pointed at the tips, distinguishing it from other sub-species of Potamogeton obtusifolius. The plant produces small, green flowers that are clustered in spike-like inflorescences, and it often grows in shallow, slow-moving waters. It plays an important role in aquatic ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various aquatic organisms. Its presence is often an indicator of good water quality in its native habitats.
